newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: India oilseeds expansion hard to achieve - bank.
newsitem.headline: India oilseeds expansion hard to achieve - bank.

text.p: India's plan to produce 26 million tonnes of oilseeds from 18 million in 1994/95 looks very ambitious, Dutch agri-bank Rabobank said in a report on the country's agribusiness.
The main way for the country to raise output was through an increase in productivity rather than by expanding area.
But here two factors were likely to limit growth.

The first related to climate, with production highly dependent on the monsoon. "More than 75 percent of India's oilseed is grown in rainfed areas, which makes the production susceptible to weather fluctuations," it said.
Secondly, high prices for inputs such as phosphates would also limit their use and curb productivity.
But the report said the industry offered potential for foregn investors, particularly in upgrading and modernising facilities.

"Since quality has become a key feature of world market trade, this is what India should focus on in the production and processing of oilseeds....possibly with the help of foreign investors," it said.
India also needed to tackle the bottlenecks that have restricted exports and limited efficient use of processing capacity.

"The problems that Indian exporters face concern high transportation costs and time delays because of deficient transport facilities. This situation has been aggravated by the congestion in the major ports," the report said.
